Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data

hello barry.

On 2012-04-04 6:07 , Barry Norton wrote:
> I thought REST was about identifying resources and interacting with them
> using a uniform interface (commonly via HTTP). In the meantime it's
> about accepting that a common centralised bunch of link relations are
> all the shared semantics that are needed and the rest can just be pushed
> into local schemas with no sharing.

at least from my understanding of what we've been doing over the last 
couple of years, we never "changed" what REST is about. the uniform 
interface always was and still is a central building block of REST, it's 
what works because of URIs. but before you can use the uniform interface 
of a resource that has been identified, you have been linked there, by a 
typed linked that tells you about that resource in the context of the 
application scenario, and thus what it means to interact with that 
resource ("if you GET that picture, it is something that you can embed 
in the rendering of the HTML you're currently trying to display."). 
typed links always have been another essential building block of REST, 
because without them, you would never be pointed to a resource in the 
first place, and then be able to use its uniform interface. if you look 
at HTML's link types 
(http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2009/10/links-in-html.html), i think 
it's fair to say that "a centralized bunch of link relations" (in that 
case defined as part of HTML and not as standalone link types) have been 
at the very core of how the web works, why it works, and why it has been 
successful. without those link types (i.e., with an HTML only containing 
untyped generic links), the web certainly would have been a radically 
different thing, and personally, i don't think it would have succeeded. 
anyway, the point i am trying to make here is that link relation types 
are and have always been essential to REST, and whether they are defined 
as an integral part of a media type, or externally and thus can be 
reused across media types, is more of a side issue.

cheers,

dret.
